title: Voluntary Prayers
introduction: Voluntary (nafl and sunnah) prayers are a beautiful way to draw closer to Allah beyond the five daily obligations. They bring extra reward, make up for shortcomings in our obligatory prayers, and nurture a stronger, more loving connection with our Creator. These prayers show our eagerness to please Allah and deepen our spiritual discipline.

sections.heading: Types of Voluntary Prayers
sections.content: There are many kinds of voluntary prayers:    - **Sunnah Mu’akkadah:** Regular sunnah prayers strongly encouraged by the Prophet ﷺ, like the two rak’ahs before Fajr and the two or four before and after Dhuhr.    - **Tahajjud:** The night prayer prayed after Isha and before Fajr, especially in the last third of the night when Allah’s mercy is abundant: 'And in some parts of the night offer the prayer with it as an additional prayer for you...' (Quran 17:79).    - **Duha (Forenoon Prayer):** Offered after sunrise until before Dhuhr; a means of gratitude and extra reward.    - **Other prayers:** Like the two rak’ahs after Wudu, the prayer of need (*Salat al-Hajah*), or greeting the mosque (*Tahiyyat al-Masjid*).

sections.heading: Benefits of Voluntary Prayers
sections.content: The Prophet ﷺ said that on the Day of Judgment, if a person’s obligatory prayers are lacking, Allah will complete them with their voluntary prayers. Voluntary prayers bring calmness to the heart, increase blessings, and invite Allah’s love. In a famous hadith Qudsi, Allah says: 'My servant continues to draw near to Me with nawafil (supererogatory) deeds until I love him…' (Sahih Bukhari). These extra acts strengthen our taqwa (God-consciousness) and help us stay focused on what truly matters.

sections.heading: How to Perform Them
sections.content: Perform voluntary prayers with sincerity, purely for Allah’s pleasure. Choose recommended times, like early morning or the peaceful hours of the night. Keep your prayers calm and unhurried — they are moments to connect deeply with Allah. If possible, pray in private as the Prophet ﷺ said, the best prayers after the obligatory ones are those done at home, showing humility and sincerity. Build consistency by starting with a few rak’ahs and adding more over time.

conclusion: Adding voluntary prayers to your routine strengthens your faith, discipline, and love for Allah. They are a special way to seek forgiveness, ask for help, and thank Allah for His countless blessings. May Allah accept our prayers and make us among those who stand in prayer often.
